text:
:)  

Although now that I think about it, there is something so musical and uniquely beautiful about silence. It's not appreciated enough nowadays, I find. Pure silence, that is. I'd love to pay tribute to silence by dying in it. I don't know... it's a tough choice to make.

author: Henson63

text:
@saladshootavvv
I agree with you that most people don't actually "LISTEN" to music and therefore don't have a very deep appreciation of music.
What I disagree with is what you said earlier about people claiming to like classical music but not being able to differentiate between composers, and the common misuse of "song" being a big deal.
My mistake on that composer, you got me there. Either way though, people are constantly exposed to classical music without any context. That much is still true.
author: Cheeseman

text:
@saladshootavvv Music considers every single note. Take music theory before you start arguing such things.

A Augmented sixth chord is music. It is not a composition by itself, as you say..
author: guitarskills2

text: @saladshootavvv "an artistic form of auditory communication incorporating instrumental or vocal tones in a structured and continuous manner" is the definition I got.
author: guitarskills2

text:
@saladshootavvv
Continued:
>you need knowledge to understand what you're listening to
I said nothing about "understanding", and neither did you before I replied to you. "I run into people that claim to LIKE Classical music"
Please do not put words in my mouth.
Lots of classical composers today? Well, yes. However, my response was based on your list of composers that people who claim to like classical music can't differentiate between, none of which are particularly current.
author: Cheeseman

text:
@saladshootavvv
Continued:
>they might "enjoy it but (...) They don't hear the motif that is brought back andÔªø is now soaring in the trumpets, they don't hear the transition from anguish to euphoria and the development in the symphonies
Yes they do, if they stop and listen.
Either way, you were talking about being able to differentiate between various composers and their styles. That has literally NOTHING to do with recognizing a good composition, or enjoyment.
author: Cheeseman
Cheeseman

author: Meaty Fishoil

text:
@saladshootavvv
So people aren't allowed to say they enjoy classical music unless they have a great degree of knowledge about classical musicians?
Classical music is essentially public domain stuff now. It's everywhere. People hear classical music all the time without being given any context like who wrote it, or when. That sure as hell doesn't mean they can't enjoy it, though.
I mean, I'm sorry, but to say people need to be very knowledgeable to enjoy something comes off as elitist.
author: Cheeseman

text: @saladshootavvv I'm not talking about any specific piece. I am saying that the word "song" does not mean that it must have vocals. "song" is an overlying term for any piece of music.
author: guitarskills2

text:
@saladshootavvv
I did not take it out of context. You said "no one" and I interpreted it as "no one", which is doubly justified by the fact that just a comment or 2 back we were talking about the general public.
>Look at what I wrote to guitarskills about how "instrumental song" is a bad term. That's theÔªø harm. 
WHATS the harm? Just because it's an oxymoron according to a definition that the general public hasn't used in ages?
